description: I have been a part time resident of Newport for the past two years, and when not in Newport, my family and I reside in New York City, where we are used to cars and pedestrians sharing the road. Most of the time, I find the cars here to be very respectful of pedestrians in crosswalks, however, I suspect that in summer months with an influx of tourists, some of whom may be confused about where they are going, I have been mid crosswalk on two different intersections of Marlborough (With Thames and with Farewell), during which cars have proceeded into the intersection and stopped a foot or so away from me as I have been crossing with my infant son and toddler daughter. One incident was a Thursday night, one a Saturday in July and August, both around 6/6:30. In both instances, other cars and pedestrians have been appalled at the brazenness of the driver when a mother a child are crossing in a crosswalk and already in the road. I think the police presence on Thames helps remind drivers to share the road, and based on my experience, in the summer months, I feel that such a presence on Marlborough would also be helpful. I am truly shocked at the carelessness of drivers in the presence of small children.
reporter.name: CMarcoux
request_type.title: Other
summary: Aggressive driving on Marlborough on summer nights

description: As a resident of Farewell St, I have observed a disturbingly high rate of cars going the wrong way down our one way street. If myself or others are outside, we try to warn the drivers, but I have witnessed incidents where cars going the right way have had to swerve on to the sidewalk to avoid a head on collision. This poses an obvious danger to drivers and pedestrians, and is especially concerning since many cars are picking up speed anticipating leaving town. I have observed this happening roughly daily on Thursday through Sunday, typically in the late afternoon and evening. I don’t know if additional signage would help or police presence, but it happens with such regularity that I am very worried about a serious accident taking place.
reporter.name: CMarcoux

description:
NEWPORT, RI—A section of Bellevue Avenue will close on Wednesday while National Grid completes work from an earlier job, police said. The construction starts around 7 a.m. and lasts until 4 p.m. The company will be pouring concrete. Police said the "work includes the full excavation of concrete panels and pouring of new concrete in the northbound lane" of Bellevue from Memorial Boulevard to Prospect Hill Street.

Great News, winter must be over.  Might I also suggest that there is a need for more full concrete panel restoration in the southbound lane of Bellevue at Dexter, near the Elms.  Hopefully it is also on the schedule to comply with City of Newport Ordinance 12.08.070 mandating full slab concrete replacement at the expense of the party who made the roadway cut.

description: There is a champagne colored sedan parked outside the residence at the corner of Second street and pine street. It has been in this spot for almost 6 days with no sign of an owner. Residents of the building normally use this spot frequently in a fair way as it becomes available as it has the most convenient access to the building. There are residents that have small children who have been forced to cross the busy street everyday and also residents who often have to carry heavy items to and from the building due to their jobs. The vehicle has been parked in this spot for over a week. Usually all residents of the building have a fair chance of parking in this spot or the spot directly behind it. Our ask is that someone please remove this vehicle from the spot if it has been abandoned or to locate the owner and explain that the spot is for all residents use especially those with heavy loads or children. Up until now there have been no issues with sharing these spaces and we would like to continue use of these convenient spaces.if the owner is no longer able to drive the vehicle we ask that they have someone move the vehicle to another location across the street so the rest of the residents who DO drive can have a fair chance to utilize those spaces

description:
Manholes on Thames on Feb. 7 were opened by department employees. When they were put back the noises when cars went over them could be heard up and down upper Thames.
This has been an issue in the past. I used this Click it in April 2016 to rectify the situation. Gaskets were finally put in on the nearest manhole in front of 77 Thames Street seven months later.
Things were fine until yesterday. The two employees were polite and said they would look into it, but the noise is still there and heavy traffic makes the situation more than annoying.
I'm retired and in my 70's as is my next-door neighbor. We have been living here for decades and don't want to throw our backs out repositioning these covers.
Gaskets I was told were used the last time. I hope I don't have to wait seven months for this issue again to be resolved.
Thank you

In the four months that I have lived at this address, I have seen no fewer than five car accidents on Young St., including both sideswiped parked vehicles (serious damage) and smashed vehicles at both the Spring and Thames intersections. This morning, I discovered that my parked vehicle had been sideswiped with minimal but still annoying damage.
I respectfully submit that either Young St. ought to be only one way or there should be very clear signposting that it is indeed two- way. I also think there ought to be a stop sign on Spring at the intersection with Bowery/Young, since that is essentially a blind corner for us, and people drive far too fast down Spring St. I might also recommend putting in a traffic camera to catch all the ridiculous side-swiping going on, since all but one of the ones I've seen have been hit-and-runs.

description: Heading out of Newport, there are no warning signs before the left lane abruptly ends at the bottleneck leading to the traffic signal. There is one sign on the right that says "MERGE" - it's at the merge, not before it, and is routinely ignored or just not seen by speeding vehicles in the left lane. There is plenty of room in the median to warn left-lane vehicles of the upcoming merge to the right. I previously reported this & was told it's a state road, so the issue was turned over to them. Surprise! Nothing at all has happened, and I'm sick and tired of nearly being sideswiped by the road-hogs in the left lane just because I'm obeying the speed limit. This is dangerous, and the lack of response is disheartening. Please get things moving.

description: The notorious left-lane merge at the bottleneck approaching the light at Aquidneck Ave. has never been properly marked. Any time of year, particularly summer, cars traveling in the right-hand lane risk being cut off or sideswiped by surprised (and possibly distracted) left-lane vehicles who suddenly run out of road at the merge. There is one sign that warns of the merge. It's on the right side, RIGHT AT THE MERGE, no advance warning. There needs to be signage WELL IN ADVANCE OF THE MERGE, in the MEDIAN, where those left-lane vehicles are much more likely to see and act rationally.
reporter.name: Karen Nash
request_type.title: Traffic Sign/Pavement Marking Issue

description: I traverse the intersection at Broadway and Farewell at the top of Washington Sq. Several time a day going to and from my office on Touro and home in The Point.  On average once every other day a vehicle (usually out of state plates) coming down Broadway into the Square fails to stop at the intersection.  The sole existing Stop sign for those vehicles is out of the line of sight by the Fastnet Pub.  Either "Stop" must be painted on the pavement or additional signage needs to be installed.  It's a dangerous intersection and this should be addressed.  Feel free to contact me at work 849-1319. Mark

description:
Bellevue Avenue Sidewalk Complete Surface Deterioration Dangerous and Uncomfortable for Pedestrians (Along the entire avenue on both sides from Bailey's Beach to the Newport Casino, Tennis Hall of Fame):

I absolutely agree that the Bellevue Avenue sidewalks need to be redone! They are not only extremely uncomfortable to walk along, even in good tennis shoes, but also very dangerous for many pedestrians and joggers. If Newport wants to maintain status as a world class tourist destination, i.e. the improvements of Gilded Age mansions by the Preservation Society of Newport County, then the Bellevue Avenue sidewalks must be improved. This is an investment in the future of Newport and can't be taken lightly. I have been advocating for years about the need to improve Bellevue, including repairs to the constantly broken pedestrian cross-walk signals. Which, by the way still only partially work even though I was assured they had been repaired multiple times. - Please help repair the Bellevue Avenue sidewalks, it is the most important pedestrian walkway in Newport - because although one might think "wouldn't people rather take a car or bus to visit the mansions?" - my answer is no, because the point of coming here is to slow down for a few days, relax and enjoy a pace of life once primarily experienced on foot in conversation with friends and family. That is the point of this great city. Let's not ruin that experience for generations to come by being the generation who dropped the ball and failed to maintain the city's most basic infrastructure. - Rob
reporter.name: RobNPT
request_type.title: Roadway or Sidewalk Issue

description:
Bellevue Avenue Sidewalks:
We've been discussing the deplorable condition of the deteriorated chip-seal surface of the Bellevue sidewalks for years but nothing has been done. It makes me wonder if the City Council members have ever actually tried to walk on Bellevue. This is the premier tourist area in the City and we encourage walking, yet the walking surface is so difficult and dangerous that many people, including those pushing baby carriages walk in the street.   The condition also violates ADA and the City could be sued by an aggrieved elderly or disabled resident or visitor. ADA aside, the City Council should recognize the importance of providing a comfortable and safe walking surface for residents and visitors. The City should make the repair/resurfacing of the Bellevue sidewalks a priority. Whatever is done must be historically appropriate, but maintainable.  Some options are brick pavers, a proper redo of the chip-seal possibly with smaller aggregate, or regular bituminous (asphalt) paving with a light color aggregate that will be exposed over time. Stone dust could be added on the surface to 'age' the initial look of the black asphalt. I think we can come up with good options and do some sample areas. But we have to get it into the City budget.
reporter.name: Bruce Leish
request_type.title: Roadway or Sidewalk Issue

description:
The walk signals that interface with the traffic light at the  intersection of America's Cup and Thames St were changed sometime this past year or so such that they are only activated when a pedestrian hits the button to request a walk signal.

This poses a real safety issue that I've personally witnessed MULTIPLE times over the past months.  The old walk signals changed automatically, so you always knew where you were in the whole traffic light / safe-to-cross process. Now, the walk signal is always set to default orange (no-go), and if a pedestrian hits the button even ONE SECOND after the light turns red (and they should be able to walk), the walk signal does NOT activate.  They have to wait through an entire traffic light cycle, which is very long.

This would be nothing more than a minor inconvenience EXCEPT...pedestrians who hit the button but don't get a walk signal see the traffic stopped in both directions.  Yet they don't have that walk signal. So they wait...5 seconds, 10 seconds, 20 seconds....finally they start to think, "I could have crossed 5 times by now,  this traffic signal must be broken" -- and so they step out into the street. And of course, the light now changes and they are in the middle of a busy intersection at the absolute wrong time.

I am pretty certain that any traffic engineer who studied this intersection would agree that these walk signs should change *automatically*, and not be dependent upon pedestrians hitting the button and then waiting through two traffic light cycles unnecessarily (or stepping out onto the street when they don't really know if they should).

Thanks!  Love this new seeclickfix system.  And props to Newport's traffic team!
reporter.name: An anonymous SeeClickFix user
request_type.title: Traffic Sign/Pavement Marking Issue

description:
An interesting incident happened yesterday concerning the handicap women's stall and the baby changing station, that is installed in that stall. One of the Bathhouse members was using the baby changing station, that is provided for member use, to change her baby at the same time a member in a wheelchair needed to use the handicap stall. The woman in the wheelchair waited but it seems this has happened before and she could not wait and her helper tried to get her into a regular stall, which are not made to hold 2 people let alone a wheelchair.

The question is, why was the changing station installed in the handicap stall instead of on the wall opposite the showers as it was in the old bathrooms. At this time we have 3 handicap women, to my knowledge, that are in wheelchairs or those walkers with seats and one man who require the use of the handicap stalls and quite of number of babies and toddles that require the changing stations.

I have been in a number of public restrooms and have never seen the baby changing station in the handicap stall, it has always been on a wall near the sinks.

It would appear that the better solution would be to move the baby changing station to the wall opposite the shower stalls.

description:
I'm so upset and frustrated it might be hard for me to say this coherently. I wrote a couple of weeks ago about mowing the wildflowers on the berm around the pond.  I was heartened that they hadn't mowed in these past weeks and the flowers were starting to make a come back. I wrote to thank you and mentioned how we saw 3 butterflies which is a good sign. The walk around the pond used to be one of the nicest places in Newport. Every time they would mow it looked like a dust bowl with the ugly cement rick rack showing.
Today the are mowing the berm again and in no time the daisies, clover and other flowers were cut to the quick. 
I don't know who gives the orders to cut but, they obviously have little knowledge of natural landscaping, the need for butterflies, birds and bees and ascetics. Please whoever is giving the orders STOP MOWING the berm.

description:
I am requesting that the berm around Easton Pond Reservoir not be mowed so that the wild flowers can grow again. When the discussions were held for the restoration of the berm it was decided that rick rack ( I think that's what it's called) be used so that vegetation would grow up through it thus restoring the wild flowers. One of the reasons we located to this side of town was because of the path around the pond. It was lined with wild flowers attracting all sorts of butterflies and birds. Now  however they continually mow it and it's like a dust bowl with the cement visible. It's truly ugly. There are other neighbors who also find it an eyesore. I hope you will take this into consideration.
Thank you,
Barbara Hughes.

description: Badly broken red brick sidewalk running alongside Aquidneck Park (Newport Public Library and King Mansion) along Bowery Street at Bowery Court from Spring Street up to Anthony Street has not been repaired. Months ago yellow barricades were erected along the sidewalk but no repairs done. The barricades continue to be damaged and re-erected with yellow caution tape. Barricades on one side and trucks blocking the sidewalk on opposite side of street are making it necessary to walk in the middle of a dangerously busy Bowery Street. Something must be done as soon as possible to repair this sidewalk, not only is it clearly a safety hazard to walk along it, hence the yellow barricades, but also the barricades have created an even more dangerous pedestrian situation along Bowery Street.
reporter.name: RobNPT
request_type.title: Roadway or Sidewalk Issue

address: Bellevue Avenue And Narragansett Avenue Newport, Rhode Island
description: Dangerous broken pedestrian cross-walks on all four corners at the intersection of Bellevue Avenue & Narragansett Avenue in Newport, Rhode Island. This pedestrian cross-walk has not worked in over a year and it is very dangerous to cross without getting nearly hit by speeding cars at this very busy intersection. The problem is that when the traffic lights change, the cross-walk signals never change to "walk," there is only ever a red "don't walk" hand signal on all four corners. I have almost been hit by cars at the intersection many times, witnessed near-accidents and have seen other walkers, joggers and tourists confused as when to cross, almost run over by vehicles turning. Tourism season in Newport is beginning and the mansions along Bellevue Avenue (including the Preservation Society of Newport County which has its headquarters on this intersection) are central to pedestrian activity, not to mention that Narragansett Avenue leads to the 40 Steps and Cliff Walk. Please have this cross-walk checked and repaired as soon as possible, I would hate for anyone to get hurt or worse, killed by the neglect of the City of Newport. I have included images all taken on April 4, 2016 which show the busy intersection, cross-walk and light poles, none of which showed any sign of a visible identification number as requested.
reporter.name: RobNPT
request_type.title: Roadway or Sidewalk Issue

description:
Utility cut on Bellevue at Casino Terrace intersection repaired with asphalt -- Not in accordance with City of Newport Ordinance 12.08.070
J.
Any individual, corporation, public utility or activity that performs work in, upon, or effecting the roadway of Bellevue Avenue shall be required, as a condition of the issuance of a permit to cut the roadway, to repair and replace the roadway only in full slab units. All costs relative to the repair and replacement of slabs is to be borne by the individual, corporation, public utility or activity requesting the slab for which the director of public services shall require a completion bond for all such work. Contractors performing the work shall be approved by the director of public services. The slabs shall be of the same color, texture, thickness, etc. All concrete roadway slab replacements shall be the same as the standards of the department of public services engineering division and/or the Rhode Island Department of Transportation's Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction, 2004, as amended and shall further be the same as the specifications of the Bellevue Avenue Reconstruction Contract, identified as Rhode Island Federal Aid Project No. CRP-FY89 (003)

address: Powell Ave And Broadway Newport, Rhode Island
description:
For years, there was a crosswalk at the corner of Powell Ave. and Broadway, 
which was utilized by many people on a daily basis;  that street corner is a major access point to the entrance of the Newport Hospital and all the other medical offices on Powell Ave, and daily, a number of people cross Broadway there at that corner for that reason.  In addition, there is a bus-stop there, and daily families are meeting at that corner and having to cross the road at the bus stop.  After the recent re-paving project, the crosswalk disappeared and never came back. With so much foot-traffic going to the Hospital and as a BusStop for children right there on that street corner, the crosswalk is needed to help make a safer crossing area and to help calm the traffic speed as well.  Without that crosswalk in the roadway, cars seem to be driving even faster than ever after getting through the Friendship St. traffic light driving south on Broadway at that point…the visual cue of the crosswalk at least gives drivers a sense to keep their eyes open for pedestrians. Please help to bring back that crosswalk, it will help make for a safer corner/block to walk on that block, and to cross, and get around those streets. Seeing children &  families on their way to buses, and seeing people rushing to get to the hospital as well, crossing in that way, makes it so clear that a crosswalk just needs to be restored to that place. It seems like a simple solution to bring it back;  most of the other Broadway crosswalks were restored and many even enhanced with the Yellow “Caution” stand-up signs on them (Yes!) since the re-paving, and it would make sense to do the same with this one.
reporter.name: Christopher Carbone
request_type.title: Roadway or Sidewalk Issue

description: As a homeowner on Gibbs Ave and a mother of two small children, I am nauseated at the high speed of traffic between Eustis and Broadway. It's like a race to cruise through the gauntlet as fast as possible. The sidewalks have become on ramps for vehicles reaching the bottleneck and just can't wait their turn to proceed. A stop sign and speed limit is a joke; speeds are ridiculous & the stop sign is just viewed as a suggestion.  I have not only been feet away from SUV's jumping the curb, I witnessed my neighbor hoist her child up while crossing the street just enough for a car to whizz by. Our indoor cat snuck out and was hit also. I am afraid to let my children walk down the sidewalk. Now, what's is it going to take to get the city to take some action? I've written emails to Officer Hayes, Justin Laughlin, & spoken to Eric Earls.
reporter.name: Shannon
summary: Speedbump & Speed Limit Enforcement on Gibbs

description:
At the corner of Thames and Wellington sits Firehouse Pizza.  What could be an attractive corner with the Wellington Plaza and the starting point, as the signs designate for Ocean Drive, as well as the gateway to the 5th Ward neighborhood, is instead, marred by the vulgar appearance of Firehouse Pizza.  A few observations:

Exterior:
1 The graffiti which has been “tagged” on the façade and interior of this historical building is not art, it is disgusting.
2.  The parking lot is not well kept, overgrown weeds, an empty sign post, and uncollected trash.  
3. The outside seating area appears to be a collection of unwanted restaurant equipment and a massive mistake of artistic design.
4. The front (Thames St.) entrance has broken windows, outdated fliers/ advertisement, and routinely has beer bottles, cigarettes butts and weeds growing from the building, etc… 
5.  The South side of the building (facing Asterisk restaurant) has several windows which have fallen out and or have missing panes of glass.


Interior:
Having dined at Firehouse Pizza for the better part of its’27yr operational life, the food has steadily declined and only raises two major concerns: is this really a functioning restaurant that has been  thoroughly inspected by health inspectors OR is this some sort of guise for an alternate business which, by the above mentioned items and the overall demeanor and appearance of staff and the majority of the patrons would suggest, perhaps, a more lucrative form of business than selling bad pizza and subs.

Two neighboring restaurants to Firehouse Pizza are both extremely presentable and upstanding.  Is there a different standard for Firehouse Pizza which accepts the aforementioned conditions as that which speaks to the best interest of the greater Newport community?  

Enough is enough; Newport city officials, do something.  Residents, stop tolerating such inaction by the City and by the owner(s) of Firehouse Pizza.
reporter.name: Dosomething

description: I cannot tell you how many times I have nearly been mowed down by a car while crossing Wellington Avenue in one of the designated crosswalks. Considering that families, mothers pushing strollers, the elderly, Little League ballplayers, and children must cross Wellington to use King Park, we must do more to ensure that people  let pedestrians cross safely and slow down. (Too often, motorists, having endured the snail's pace of Thames Street traffic, speed along Wellington.) I once stood in the crosswalk to force cars to stop and let a young girl cross. While this problem occurs year round, it is far too common during the summer. The high volume of parked cars on Wellington near the crosswalks makes it harder for pedestrians to see cars and for motorists to see pedestrians, making a dangerous situation even worse.

description: Sadly (although not surprisingly) a woman was hit by a car while crossing Memorial Boulevard today. description:
There is a small passageway at the Southeast corner of the Mary Street parking lot leading to Trinity Church. It is filthy, with piles of leaves, trash, graffiti, and who knows what else. What a wonderful view on your way to praise God.
====
In the past few weeks someone has indeed visited and cleaned out the trash, but the graffiti remain. It remains an embarrassment.
====
3/4/11
It has its ups and downs, but the graffiti returns as does the trash. It is clearly a thorn in the side of the City as they alternate between repainting it, ignoring it, locking it, and so forth.

I don't know the right answer. Perhaps if we were to brick it, or at least brick the pavement then it would be more attractive and less subject to violation...

Yes I know there are more important things on the City agenda, but this one does affect a lot of people at a very special time in their week. We need to address it collectively.
reporter.name: Andy Lavarre

description:
When the house  burned down Christmas 2007 the heat melted the street between the house and the Harbor House. It still hasn't been fixed.
Half a  block on the repeated freezing of a spring runoff has fractured the street and again at the corner of Washington and the SE corner of Battery Park.

This section needs a lot of TLC.

=====
6/21/10

Well, delighted to report that the first part of this has been fixed, but disappointed to report that the rest has not. I'll close this part, but the damage from the spring continues.

And, as winter approaches, will only get worse. 

The solution seems obvious and easy, I've done it myself before: 

1. Plant a willow tree over the spring.

2. Dig up the spring and divert the flow to 
     a. a well cistern (preferably so someone can use the water in a controlled fashion) or 
     b. at least to a storm drain.

If the landowner doesn't want the cistern then put it under Battery Park and use it for either a dog trough or a sprinkler system for the park lawn, with overflow to the bay...
reporter.name: Andy Lavarre
